bibl.title: Abstract: Yellow Fever, edited by Henry Rose Carter, 1923

div1.p: Carter comments on recent yellow fever articles and summarizes yellow fever work. He discusses the relation of Leptospira icteroides to yellow fever and the use of curative sera. He also mentions the recent yellow fever outbreaks in Brazil, Colombia, and West Africa.

div1.head: Abstract: Yellow Fever, edited by Henry Rose Carter, 1923
div1.opener:
Miscl-
Nelson Loose-Leaf
March 1/23-Oct. 1/23
YELLOW FEVER.
Edited by H. R. Carter.
div1.p:
Not many articles of value have been published within the six
months ending Oct. 1/23 on the above subject. The most important, in the
opinion of the writer, have been those involving the rather general accept-
ance in practisce of the Leptospira icteroides as without question its cau-
sative organism. The reactions of the serum of patients sick or conval-
escent of suspected yellow fever with cultures of this organism have been
used in a number of places (Mexico: Colombia: Brazil) as determinative of
the disease suffered from and the results seem to have been be consistent with the
clinical and epidemiological data.

On the same basis, the use of the curative serum, when used early,
is shown by the protocols reported as having given markedly good results in the epidemic in
French West Africa.

The diagnostic value of the serological reactions spoken of above are
far more valuable in determining what the patient has had, when convales-
cent, than as a means of diagnosis during the acute sickness as they are
not reported as showing early in the disease. Perez Grovas of Mexico, for
instance, (vide infra) finds that the serum acquires agglutinative proper-
ties “by the beginning of the second week”; at which time the attack is
over, the aphorism still holding that “if not past hope by the end of the
5th. day, he recovers,” and the 7th. being the day on which most deaths
occur.

Still a certainty of diagnosis in recovered cases may be of very
great value to the sanitarian.

The regions specially attacked during the six months above mentioned
have been

1/ Brazil: roughly from Ceara (Fortaleza) to Bahia. Infection in

Ceara especially threatens the rubber country on the upper Amazon around
Manaos and Iquitos--free from infection certainly since 1915.
2/ The town of Bucaramanga in the N. E. part of Colombia.

3/ Portions of the Gulf of Guinea in West Africa (the Gold and
Ivory Coast), where none was found by the expedition (Noble C
Guiteras) of the I. H. B. in 1920

There has been no report of yellow fever in Mexico or Central America
during this time (or since) and there is good reason to believe that it
has been eliminated from the North American continent as well as from the
Pacific coast of both Americas. In Connor's article then, abstracted be-
low, one may be justified in saying that his statement: “there are at
least three areas in Mexico where the disease in endemic” should be
changed to “there were.”

Africa: A number of the articles upon the African fever show lit-
tle acquaintance with the epidemiological problems which have been work-
ed out elsewhere. They are valuable for the data which they contain
andbut in many cases their deductions from it are not justified, e. g. White
(vide infra) states there is no evident endemic center in West Africa,
meaning there is no one town or section always infected. He ignores en-
tirely the doctrine of the regional centerfocus in which, in a large region, some
place (not the same place, of course) is always infected, the infection
travelling from place to place and being always present somewhere in the
region. In attempting to explain the outbreaks from time to time on the
Gold Coast he states that the “indigenous natives” were “incapable of main-
taining the virus” the fever; becoming milder and milder among them until
it ceases to have power to infect anyone. He does not advance (and there
is not) one iota of evidence for this and there is considerable against
it. This deduction which he draws from Peterson's paper on the Spontaneous
Disappearance of the disease in the Virgin Islands is absolutely repudiated
by Peterson himself, as it is by the writer is the claim, that it the deduction is sustained
by his doctrine of the Spontaneous Elimination of Yellow Fever by Failure
Failure
3
of the Human Host; and his the; further statement that change of residence
causes loss of immunity to yellow fever is a partial revival of the old
doctrine of Mithradatism, so prevalent about the middle of the last Cen-
tury, but which the writer thinksought had been held by no student of yellow
fever since it was laid to rest by the papers of Chaillé (1881) and Gui-
teras (1888).

In point of fact, yellow fever is kept up in West Africa by attacks
among the natives, which when confined to them (on account of their mild-
ness) are not noted. The whites are not in sufficient number in this
part of Africa to keep up the disease, but since they have it with severity
it is readily recognized when it occurs among them and gives rise to the
report of yellow fever.

In other words, the African preserves the infection from one re-
ported outbreak to another while the whites serve as indicators of its
existence.

The following articles have appeared in the period March 1, 1923 to
October 1, 1923.

Grovas, P. P.: Serological Reactions in Yellow Fever, Am. J. Trop.
Med. 3:325, 1923. In agglutination tests on the serum of 183 yellow fever
cases, 17 cases of other diseases, and 23 normal persons, it was found
that the serum acquires agglutinating properties in yellow fever patients
by the beginning of the second week of the disease; the agglutination
test was negative in diseases other than yellow fever and in normal per-
sons, but positive in recently vaccinated individuals. Pfeiffer's re-
action was positive in 17 patients convalescing from yellow fever, but
was negative in one case on the eight day of the disease. The comple-
ment fixation test in yellow fever did not prove satisfactory. The
author concludes that the agglutination test is the most practical and
satisfactory for diagnosis.
